review_title: Stand firm on salary, work/life balance.
job_title: Specialist in New York, NY
pros: Helping to save lives of beautiful, amazing people. Some of the most influential, heartfelt projects of my career. Initiatives were steadily improving under the new CEO.
cons: I was there during a bad time, with silo-ism and warlike pontificating between departments. There was money mismanagement at the very top, resulting in massive layoffs in several large waves. *Make sure to stand your ground regarding salary at the time of interview. I was brought in by a recruiter, and during my interviews the initial salary offer was lowballed to 10k less. This was a serious mistake for me to accept, since commuting time/costs had a negative impact. Toward the end of my time there, I also found out I was the lowest paid in my department while others with less experience and doing less were being paid much more. So again, be firm with negotiating your salary because the raises may not happen.

review_title: Exciting times, but workplace culture issues
job_title: Manager in New York, NY
pros:
NYBC operates in a very price-competitive industry (blood banking) which is creating a lot of pressure to cut costs as well as opportunities to stand out among blood banks. They are well positioned to do this because they have the resources to acquire and partner with other blood banks and service providers, and they have the scientific expertise to innovate, leading to new products and services in blood banking, transfusion medicine, cell therapy, etc.

All in all, there are a lot of exciting initiatives and changes going on at NYBC. As an employee, this can translate into opportunities to get involved in new strategic initiatives, particularly if you are entrepreneurial and you (and/or your supervisor) are well positioned.
cons:
NYBC can be a frustrating place when it comes to new initiatives, particularly those that require senior level support, because there are some significant horizontal silos - i.e. communication or collaboration gaps between layers of management, starting at the board of trustees and downwards. This is an organization of gatekeepers. The leadership realizes that a more agile and integrated culture is needed, and some managers are helping bring this to reality.

Depending on the department/division, there are few opportunities for upward mobility - promotions, raises, etc. The organization has a hard time holding on to young, ambitious employees who want to learn and want to follow a career development track. That said, there is a tuition-reimbursement program should you decide to work full-time while in school.

job_title: Assistant Member in New York, NY
pros: none none and none and none
cons: disrespectful to any one including internal staff

job_title: Anonymous Employee in New York, NY
pros: The benefits package is the only pro. Other then that I would NOT recommend this company to anyone! People are promoted to managerial and supervisory positions and have NO clue how to manage or supervise anyone and what makes it worse is that NO training is provided to help these newly promoted managers and supervisors be the best that they can be. Upper management is so far disconnected with the organization that they have NO idea whats going on! The HR department is filled with people who NO one really knows besides one person, the Benefits Manager, she's the only person you can get in contact with when you call that department and its sad because most times you can tell she's two seconds away from having a mental breakdown. Everyone else who works in that department can never give you the answer you need when you call and theres always turn over, once you get familiar with someone there suddenly gone and a new person is there! I say they get rid of the entire department and start anew with a fresh staff! Your company is as strong as your HR department!
cons: Everyone is sleeping with each other and dating each other which causes for an uncomfortable work environment! Stricter guidelines need to be put in place to avoid situations like these! Oh and lets not forget that the pay is horrible! if your not upper management you get paid the bare minimum! More paid holidays would be nice as well, you only get 6 at this place!

job_title: Postdoctoral Research Fellow in New York, NY
pros: Professional organization that holds itself to high standards of accountability
cons: Power hungry mid-level managers make the life of every day employees difficult. little work life balance unless you're willing to fight for it

review_title: Good pay, GREAT benefits - too bad you'll want to kill yourself every day
job_title: Account Manager in New Brunswick, NJ
pros:
Good starting salary
Generous 401k plan
A wealth of sick/personal days
Good insurance
cons:
This place is a completely dysfunctional environment and I would not recommend working here.  The upper management plays favorites and works on a bullying tactic system.  The favorites are untouchable, but if management doesn't like you, you will have a target on your head. Targets get written up and punished for made-up rules (this isn't an exaggeration; they make up rules you've never heard of before).  Once you have a target on your head, management will make your life miserable until you quit.  But if you aren't a target, you can do the same exact thing on a daily basis without a word.  
Furthermore, the whole company works on a "blame game" system.  All the departments are pitted against each other, and when something goes wrong, everyone scrambles to find proof that the flub-up was another department's mistake.  As a result, you are encouraged to do work that will cover your department (and therefore upper management of your department) - instead of being encouraged to do productive work that would actually improve the situation, and rectify mistakes so that they don't happen again in the future (believe me, they always happen again).

job_title: Research Assistant in New York, NY
pros: Good location in Manhattan with Qtrain access, Lots of Benefits: Plum Benefits(look it up), comparatively good vacation days. Unlimited accrual of sick days, commuter benefits, health, dental, pension plan etc
cons: Low wages, The max salary increase was only up to 5%/year, Lots of politics between different PIs, No recognition for research work contributed by the lower lab members, no recognition by the org for a successfull publication in a journal, working throughout Christmas week.

job_title: in New York, NY
pros: Comparable benefits for nonprofit organization. Opportunity to advance within company.
cons: Salaries lower than comparable organizations. Communication between upper, middle management and line staff poor. Staff morale low, management makes no effort to boost camaraderie or morale due to unwillingness to spend $ on perks formerly offered, such as annual recognition event, holiday gatherings, etc.

job_title: Donor Specialist in Westbury, NY
pros: Great retirement plan, pay is a little better than most phlebotomy jobs, and good amount of sick/personal days and you are in 1199 union so you have some sort of protection and health care benefits are the best
cons: The scheduling is horrible, you are made to work every weekend for years, sometimes more than 10 years no weekends off.  If you ask to be flexed off for a weekend you end up working 9 days straight and by the time you have that weekend off you are exhausted. The hours change everyday, one day you have work at 7am and the next you could be working 2pm, management is so unorganized and plays favorites, it is always understaffed and because of that staff are constantly calling out whenever they can, you have to travel all over BUT you don’t get reimbursed for milage unless you drive over 50 miles ONE way, so prepare to abuse your car and have no money to put into it, don’t bother leasing a car you will drive on average 18,000 miles or more a year because of it, they will also mandate you left and right to work on your days off when you already have a challenging schedule, you never know what time you are getting out of work, if a donor complains about you for anything you are wrong no matter what, the office does not back you, the people in charge of you each day at these drives half of them shouldn’t even be in charge, they are either oblivious as to what goes on around them, unorganized, play favorites, can’t hustle, or lack time management skills

What's more sad that the individuals that run things are criminal against their own kind. Everyman for himself! No matter how well you perform, none of that matters. Management sleeps with who ever is willing to do so in exchange for ammunity, or to move up the ladder. Sad, sad,sad, actually it's pretty pathetic!
cons: This is a dumpster ground for all who are lazy, rats, back stabbers, & everything in between...no loyalty.

review_title: Run the other way as fast as you can
job_title: Donor Specialist 2-1 in New York, NY
pros: 401k, 26 personal days, tuition reimbursement and plenty of over time
cons:
Management is so driven by making money they can care less about employee well being. The union is a joke with the delegates themselves blocking growth and promotions. 
Let's start with management. Staff is under the worst pressure to make numbers. Blood drives and donor centers are over booked and understaffed and then expected to meet some ridiculous goal. Team leaders have gone as far as convieniently forgetting or just flat out refusing to give lunch or 15 min breaks when staff have been running around all day. Management is also way too involved in petty gossip and knowing staffs personal business for what ever reason. Promotions are reserved for management favorites, family members or childhood friends  who have no idea what they are doing. Don't even think that hard work and going above and beyond the call of duty is going to get you anywhere because it's not. It will only leave you frustrated and abused.  Let's talk about getting days off. By law you are  supposed to have 2 consecutive days off to relax and try to put what's left of your life together but not in this place they will mandate you to work on your days off even if you have already workers 36 days in a row and call it operational needs. Personal/ vacation days are hard to comne by like I said try to put what's left of your life together is not going to happen. Vacations are denied and don't bother asking for a day off or to be accommodated for a doctor's appointment or a family event. Oh and dont forget to smile and give the best customer service even when donors are being rude, disrespectful, racist and sexually harassing you because once again you don't matter to management they only want the money so who cares how you are treated it's all about the money. They have a way of making you feel humiliated and worthless from the second you walk in the door. And this is management on all levels from the team leaders all the way up to the CEO who by the way is so disconnected that when ever he finds the time to pretend he cares about anything but his bottom line and walk into any blood drive no one knows who he is. 
Now the union. If you want to be a donor specialist which is a fancy name for phlebotomist/ medical assistant you must join the union.  There is no way around that. Now with the union comes a union contract that management completely disregards is unethical and the delegates don't even know. Any contractual promotions such as person in charge again fancy name for supervisor or training promotions for learning how to use different equipment goes by seniority. Now how management gets around some people is by looking at attendances and errors and customer complaints to not give you the promotion and when that's done and mangment had no other choices and picks who ever is next that's when the union steps in and grieves the promotion because their friends where passed over. Now this process stops the promotion temporarily which gives management a second chance to find something on the current candidate so now they won't get promoted. Oh lowrd  don't get cought up in any thing that will get you a visit to the office because not only will the delegates just sit there and not say a word but they will walk out the door and tell everyone what happens. So enter the lions den at your own risk because either way you are screwed.
